Award.AwardTitle: Testing a Three-Stage Model of Institutional Confidence across Branches of Government

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project proposes and tests a theoretical model of institutional confidence that will be evaluated in the context of water regulatory institutions. This institutional confidence theory posits that changes in knowledge of and experiences with governmental institutions will affect not only levels of confidence in the institution, but also the bases used to make institutional confidence judgments. The central hypothesis is that people rely on different factors to determine their trust and confidence in a specific institution, depending on their extent of knowledge and experience with that institution. Thus, it is hypothesized that when a person has limited experience with and knows little about an institution, institutional confidence assessments will be driven by one's general disposition to trust. As one gains knowledge and experience, perceptions of the institution's trustworthiness will determine institutional confidence. With more experience, stable attitudes of loyalty or cynicism will increasingly account for confidence judgments. The methods used to test the theory are 1) validation of measures of water-related institutional constructs on two different samples; 2) a cross-sectional, community study of institutional confidence in water-regulatory institutions; and 3) a longitudinal study of confidence in water institutions.

The project is one of the first programs of research to focus on confidence in institutions that regulate water resources. These studies will provide an understanding of what specifically drives confidence attitudes and perceptions in water-related, governmental institutions. Important implications of this research include 1) effective governance for water-related institutions, given that trust and confidence in government has been shown to be associated with compliance and acceptance of governmental decisions; and 2) application to other governance contexts, such as courts and municipalities, two other governmental institutions previously studied by the research team.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project proposed and tested a theoretical model of institutional trust that was evaluated in the context of water regulatory institutions. This model posits that changes in knowledge of and experiences with governmental institutions will affect the bases used to make institutional trust judgments. The central hypothesis is that people rely on different factors to determine their trust in a specific institution, depending on their extent of knowledge and experience with that institution. It was hypothesized that when a person has limited experience with and knows little about an institution, institutional trust assessments will be driven by one's general disposition to trust. As one gains knowledge and experience, it was hypothesized that general dispositions will matter less, and that perceptions of the institution's trustworthiness will determine institutional trust. The methods used to test the theory were 1) validation of measures of water-related institutional trust constructs on two different samples; 2) a cross-sectional, community study of institutional trust in water-regulatory institutions; and 3) a longitudinal study of trust in water institutions.

 

Intellectual Merit: Relatively little research has investigated the dimensionality of the numerous trust-relevant constructs in the literature. Also, although developmental models of trust have been proposed, little to no research has been conducted examining the role that knowledge about an institution plays in the evolution of institutional trust and in potentially altering the reasons for (bases of) that trust. Further, this project is one of the first programs of research to focus on confidence in institutions that regulate water resources. Thus, this research advances understanding of the dimensionality of trust-relevant constructs and of the factors affecting trust attitudes in the domain of water-related, governmental institutions. This work also advances the literatures related to trust in environmental studies, organizational behavior, social psychology, and political science, by contributing to a more integrated view of how trust in institutions evolves over time.

 

Broader Impacts: A major impact of our study is upon effective governance of water-related institutions. Water regulatory institutions are governmental entities that are unfamiliar to the general public, but likely to become increasingly important as climate change impacts water availability. Trust and confidence in government has been shown to be associated with compliance and acceptance of governmental decisions. Thus a better understanding of trust is important for better institutional functioning, in environmental contexts and beyond. Our findings also lend themselves to application to other governance contexts, such as courts and municipalities, two other institutions studied by the research team.
